body: Hey @whitphx Thanks for the report! Can you describe for me the use case for experimental_rerun inside a callback? Callbacks are triggered before the rerun, so, effectively, experimental rerun should not be needed.

issue.title: Chat app does not work with Streamlit==0.89.0

repository.name: streamlit-server-state
repository.description: A "server-wide" state object shared across sessions on a Streamlit server.

issue.body:
After submitting a new message from the text input, the nickname input is reset to be empty (and the message logs disappear).

This is because session-rerun is invoked inside callbacks.
Rel: https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/3854

body:
As you said, the code above was trivial examples.
The original problem was on my [`streamlit-server-state`](https://github.com/whitphx/streamlit-server-state) library, described in https://github.com/whitphx/streamlit-server-state/issues/37 and https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/new-library-streamlit-server-state-a-new-way-to-share-states-across-sessions-on-the-server/14981/8?u=whitphx.

This library reruns sessions via `ReportSession.request_rerun()`. Yes, it's hacky and uses a private API, so not worth supporting.
In addition, thanks to your statement "Callbacks are triggered before the rerun", I found a workaround for my library: https://github.com/whitphx/streamlit-server-state/pull/38, so finally this became no longer a problem for my case.

---

However, as shown in the example above, this problem still exists with a public API `st.experimental_rerun()` and the example is possible code without any alerts.
So I think the ver. 1 code above is still worth considering to fix anyway.

Thanks for the additional info @whitphx.

As `experimental_rerun` is still in the `experimental` namespace, a fix for this may not end up being the highest priority for us. However, taking a glance at the code, I think it should actually be pretty straightforward to do, so I'll see if I can get a fix out some time in the next few weeks.

issue.title: Make calling st.experimental_rerun() within a callback a no-op

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit — A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
Since callbacks are hoisted to run before the actual script run, there's
generally no need to use the st.experimental_rerun() function within a
callback.

Currently, attempting to do so breaks the streamlit app. This PR fixes this so
that calling `st.experimental_rerun()` in a callback is a no-op, and a
warning gets printed to the user's streamlit app to warn the user of
this.

Closes #3854

issue.title: Element values are not restored properly after `st.rerun`

labels.name: status:confirmed
labels.description: Bug has been confirmed by the Streamlit team

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit — A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body: ### Summary Values of components which appear after `st.experimental_rerun()` are not restored but initialized after executing `st.experimental_rerun()` ### Steps to reproduce Code snippet: [![Open in Streamlit Cloud](https://static.streamlit.io/badges/streamlit_badge_black_white.svg)](https://issues.streamlitapp.com/?issue=gh-3533) ```python import streamlit as st radio_value = st.radio("Select1", ["Egg", "Spam", "Bacon", "Sausage"]) st.write(radio_value) if st.button("Rerun"): st.experimental_rerun() radio_value = st.radio("Select2", ["Egg", "Spam", "Bacon", "Sausage"]) st.write(radio_value) radio_value = st.radio("Select3", ["Egg", "Spam", "Bacon", "Sausage"]) st.write(radio_value) ``` 1. At first, all radio values are "Egg" 2. Change the selections; for example, "Spam", "Bacon", and "Sausage" for 3 radios respectively. Now, each radio button and its successive `st.write()` shows the selected item name. 3. Click the "Rerun" button. This triggers `st.experimental_rerun()` 4. After `st.experimental_rerun()`, **the second and third `st.write()`'s outputs are reset to "Egg"** (radio buttons selections are visually not changed though). * Rerunning without `st.experimental_rerun()` fixes this wrong state. For example, after changing the selection of some radio button which causes the script to rerun, all the component values are restored properly again. **Expected behavior:** At step 4 above, all component values are restored properly so that the second `st.write()` shows "Bacon" and the third "Sausage". **Actual behavior:** As explained above, at step 4, the second and third `st.write()` show wrong restored component values. ### Is this a regression? That is, did this use to work the way you expected in the past? no ### Debug info - Streamlit version: `Streamlit, version 0.83.0` - Python version: `Python 3.8.7` - Using Conda? PipEnv? PyEnv? Pex?: `pyenv` + `python -m venv` - OS version: macOS Big Sur, 11.4 - Browser version: Brave 1.26.74 Chromium: 91.0.4472.124（Official Build） （arm64）

issue.title: Add info on warning: Calling st.experimental_rerun() within a callback is a no-op

labels.name: type:api
labels.description: Additions and updates to API reference

repository.name: docs
repository.description: Source code for the Streamlit Python library documentation

issue.body:
**Link to doc page in question (if any):**
https://docs.streamlit.io/library/api-reference/control-flow/st.experimental_rerun
**Name of the Streamlit feature whose docs need improvement:**
st.experimental_rerun
**What you think the docs should say:**
I have encountered a puzzling warning using `st.button` callback functions. The warning states:
`Calling st.experimental_rerun() within a callback is a no-op.`

I can't find any information about this warning except this pull request which appears to implement the warning [Make calling st.experimental_rerun() within a callback a no-op](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/pull/3934) which closes this issue: [Rerunning the session does not work inside callbacks](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues/3854).

The simple test app I made using the following code triggers this warning (when buttons are pressed in succession) even though `st.experimental_rerun` is not explicitly run anywhere:

```
import streamlit as st

def left_callback():
    st.write('Left button was clicked')

def right_callback():
    st.write('Right button was clicked')

left_col, right_col, _ = st.columns([1, 1, 3])

with left_col:
    st.button('LEFT', on_click=left_callback)

with right_col:
    st.button('RIGHT', on_click=right_callback)
```

It appears that it is an issue with session state and callbacks not properly working together or the app being re-run inside one of the callbacks under the hood.

My suggestion is to add information about possible warnings that `st.experimental_rerun()` may trigger, including this one I have mentioned. Or add a functionality to suppress the warning. I don't think this is a bug, so I submit this as a documentation improvement in the hopes of getting some answers about why this warning is triggered.
